content.description: Cystic fibrosis (<math alttext="or C F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a progressive genetic disease that causes persistent lung infections and affects the ability to breathe. <math alttext="C F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, caused by the presence of mutations in both copies of the gene for the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (<math alttext="or C F T R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CFTR</mtext></mrow></math>) protein. Partial nucleotide sequences and the corresponding amino acid sequences for an unaffected individual and an affected individual are modeled in Figure 1.
content.question: Figure 1. <math alttext="C F T R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFTR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein sequences in unaffected and affected individuals Based on the information in Figure 1, which type of mutation explains the nature of the change in <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> that resulted in cystic fibrosis in the affected individual?

choices.label: Substitution, because the amino acid tryptophan is replaced with glycine.
Insertion, because an extra guanine is present, which changes the reading frame.
Deletion, because a thymine is missing, which changes the reading frame.
Duplication, because the amino acid leucine occurs twice, which changes the reading frame.

content.answer: Deletion, because a thymine is missing, which changes the reading frame.
